questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman, in her 28th week of gestation, presents to the emergency room with acute severe abdominal pain that started suddenly. She denies fever, vaginal bleeding, or regular uterine contractions. On examination, her abdomen is tense and tender. Laboratory investigations reveal a normal WBC count of 8000 cells/µl. There is no evidence of cervical dilatation or effacement. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ R ed degeneration of fibroid is a common complication in pregnancy, presenting with acute abdominal pain and tenderness, usually in the second or third trimester. Management is supportive, and surgical intervention is avoided unless absolutely necessary.
  • ➤ R ed degeneration of fibroid is a common complication in pregnancy, presenting with acute abdominal pain and tenderness, usually in the second or third trimester.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of excessive preoccupation about having a serious illness for the past year. Despite normal investigations and repeated reassurance from multiple doctors, she is convinced that she has cancer. She spends hours daily researching symptoms online and frequently seeks medical opinions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Illness anxiety disorder (Hypochondriasis) is characterized by a preoccupation with having or acquiring a serious physical illness. The preoccupation persists despite normal investigations and medical reassurances. Management includes primarily psychotherapy (CBT), and pharmacotherapy for comorbid psychiatric disorders. Preoccupation with illness- Illness anxiety disorder (Hypochondriasis) Preoccupation with somatic symptoms- Somatic symptom disorder
  • ➤ Illness anxiety disorder (Hypochondriasis) is characterized by a preoccupation with having or acquiring a serious physical illness.

  • ➤ Management includes primarily psychotherapy (CBT), and pharmacotherapy for comorbid psychiatric disorders. Preoccupation with illness- Illness anxiety disorder (Hypochondriasis) Preoccupation with somatic symptoms- Somatic symptom disorder

Ans.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida woman is in active labor. On pelvic examination, the presenting part is identified as the face, and the mentum is anterior. Based on this presentation, which of the following is true about the presentation?

options.label: A
options.text: The presenting diameter is sub-occipito bregmatic, and the labor is uneventful.

options.label: B
options.text: The presenting diameter is occipito-frontal, and the delivery will require a cesarean section.

options.label: C
options.text: The presenting diameter is sub-mento bregmatic, and vaginal delivery is possible if the mentum is anterior.

options.label: D
options.text: The presenting diameter is vertico-mental, and labor will always require a cesarean section.

questions.correct_answer: C. The presenting diameter is sub-mento bregmatic, and vaginal delivery is possible if the mentum is anterior.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Face presentation is characterized by the sub-mento bregmatic diameter when the mentum is anterior, allowing for vaginal delivery. In contrast, a posterior mentum orientation generally necessitates cesarean delivery due to obstructed labor.
  • ➤ Face presentation is characterized by the sub-mento bregmatic diameter when the mentum is anterior, allowing for vaginal delivery.
  • ➤ sub-mento bregmatic diameter
  • ➤ In contrast, a posterior mentum orientation generally necessitates cesarean delivery due to obstructed labor.

questions.text: Which of the following features best distinguishes pseudo-Pelger-Huët cells from true Pelger-Huët cells? Presence of coarse chromatin Presence of bilobed nuclei in neutrophils Association with hematologic malignancy Autosomal dominant inheritance
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 3 and 4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Pseudo-Pelger-Huët cells differ from true Pelger-Huët cells in the following ways:
  • • 3. Association with hematologic malignancy: Pseudo-Pelger-Huët anomaly is typically observed in pathological conditions such as myelodysplastic syndromes, acute myeloid leukemia, or other hematologic malignancies.
  • • 4. Autosomal dominant inheritance of true Pelger-Huët anomaly: True Pelger-Huët anomaly is a benign inherited condition with no association with malignancy.
  • • These two features, association with hematologic malignancy and autosomal dominant inheritance, are the best differentiators between pseudo-Pelger-Huët and true Pelger-Huët anomalies.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • 1 and 2: Incorrect. Both true and pseudo-Pelger-Huët cells can exhibit bilobed nuclei and coarse chromatin. These morphological features alone cannot distinguish between the two conditions.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pseudo-Pelger-Huët anomaly is associated with hematologic malignancies, whereas true Pelger-Huët anomaly is an autosomal dominant, benign condition with no pathological associations.

questions.text: A study evaluates the mortality outcomes of a specific occupational group compared to the general population. The Standardized Mortality Ratio (SMR) is used to adjust for differences in the age distribution of the two populations. Which of the following is the most accurate interpretation of an SMR of 1.5?

options.label: A
options.text: Mortality in the occupational group is 50% lower than expected based on the general population.

options.label: B
options.text: Mortality in the occupational group is 50% higher than expected based on the general population.

options.label: C
options.text: The occupational group’s mortality is equivalent to the general population after adjustment for confounders.

options.label: D
options.text: The SMR represents a direct standardization approach using the general population's age-specific mortality rates.

questions.correct_answer: B. Mortality in the occupational group is 50% higher than expected based on the general population.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The SMR is an indirect standardization method used to compare observed and expected mortality, accounting for confounding variables like age.
  • ➤ The SMR is an indirect standardization method used to compare observed and expected mortality, accounting for confounding variables like age.

questions.text: A 33-year-old pregnant woman presents for a routine antenatal checkup. She is at 33 weeks of gestation. An umbilical artery Doppler ultrasound is performed, as shown in the image. What is the next step in management?

options.text: Terminate the pregnancy at 34 weeks of gestation

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with severe pain in his gums, foul breath, and bleeding during brushing for the past week. questions.text: Assertion: Glucocorticoids inhibit fibroblast proliferation and extracellular matrix production. Reason: Glucocorticoids suppress prostaglandin and leukotriene synthesis through inhibition of cyclooxygenase (COX).

options.label: A
options.text: Both the assertion and reason are true, and the reason correctly explains the assertion.

options.label: B
options.text: Both the assertion and reason are true, but the reason does not explain the assertion.

options.label: C
options.text: The assertion is true, but the reason is false.

options.label: D
options.text: Both the assertion and reason are false.

questions.correct_answer: C. The assertion is true, but the reason is false.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that glucocorticoids inhibit phospholipase A2 , suppress fibroblast proliferation, and reduce extracellular matrix production, delaying wound healing.
  • ➤ Understand that glucocorticoids inhibit phospholipase A2 , suppress fibroblast proliferation, and reduce extracellular matrix production, delaying wound healing.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is brought to the ICU after a severe traumatic brain injury following a road traffic accident. He is unresponsive, with no spontaneous movements or brainstem reflexes on examination. Mechanical ventilation is maintaining his respiratory status. A neurologist is consulted to assess for brain death. Which of the following tests is most crucial in confirming the diagnosis of brain death based on Harvard criteria?

options.label: A
options.text: Confirmatory MRI showing irreversible damage to the brainstem and cortex

options.label: B
options.text: Presence of apnea during an apnea test after appropriate oxygenation and CO₂ monitoring

options.label: C
options.text: Bilateral absence of pupillary light reflexes without pharmacological influence

options.label: D
options.text: Isoelectric EEG recorded for a continuous period of at least 24 hours

questions.correct_answer: B. Presence of apnea during an apnea test after appropriate oxygenation and CO₂ monitoring
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brain death is a clinical diagnosis that requires unresponsiveness, absence of brainstem reflexes, and apnea confirmed by the apnea test. Confirmatory tests like EEG provide additional evidence but are not substitutes for clinical evaluation.
  • ➤ Brain death is a clinical diagnosis that requires unresponsiveness, absence of brainstem reflexes, and apnea confirmed by the apnea test.
  • ➤ Confirmatory tests like EEG provide additional evidence but are not substitutes for clinical evaluation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman, Mrs. Seema, presents with 2 weeks of worsening bilateral headaches, blurry vision, dizziness, and tingling sensation in her feet. She denies fever, night sweats, weight loss, or jaw pain but has had episodes of epistaxis. History and Examination: Medical history: Hypertension on chlorthalidone. Physical findings: Visual changes: Decreased visual acuity with dilated, segmented, tortuous retinal veins on fundoscopic exam (sausage-link appearance). Neurologic findings: Decreased pinprick sensation and loss of ankle reflexes bilaterally, suggesting peripheral neuropathy. Normal strength and moist mucous membranes. Laboratory Results: Hemoglobin: 10.2 g/dL (low) Platelets: 180,000/mm³ (normal) Total protein: 10.8 g/dL (elevated) Albumin: 3.5 g/dL (normal), indicating a high globulin gap. ESR: 90 mm/h (elevated). What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors and loop diuretics

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with hyperviscosity syndrome, peripheral neuropathy, and elevated protein with a globulin gap, suspect Waldenström macroglobulinemia and confirm with serum protein electrophoresis.
  • ➤ In patients with hyperviscosity syndrome, peripheral neuropathy, and elevated protein with a globulin gap, suspect Waldenström macroglobulinemia and confirm with serum protein electrophoresis.
  • ➤ hyperviscosity syndrome, peripheral neuropathy, and elevated protein with a globulin gap,
  • ➤ Waldenström macroglobulinemia
  • ➤ serum protein electrophoresis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man, Mr. Raghav from Bengaluru, with a 7-year history of ankylosing spondylitis (AS) presents to the clinic with persistent back pain. He describes morning stiffness and nighttime aching that improves during the day. Despite high-dose naproxen, his pain relief is now moderate. Six months ago, he had right hip pain, but imaging showed no joint involvement. Vitals: Within normal limits. Examination: Limited spinal mobility and sacroiliac joint tenderness. Laboratory findings: Hemoglobin: 10.5 g/dL (mild anemia) Platelets: 350,000/µL (normal) Creatinine: 0.8 mg/dL (normal) C-reactive protein: 11 mg/dL (elevated, indicating inflammation). What is the best next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In ankylosing spondylitis , TNF-α inhibitors (e.g., adalimumab) are the treatment of choice for persistent axial symptoms refractory to NSAIDs. Early and aggressive management prevents complications such as spinal fusion and improves functional outcomes.
  • ➤ In ankylosing spondylitis , TNF-α inhibitors (e.g., adalimumab) are the treatment of choice for persistent axial symptoms refractory to NSAIDs.

  • ➤ persistent axial symptoms
  • ➤ Early and aggressive management prevents complications such as spinal fusion and improves functional outcomes.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman in active labor is found to have a transverse lie presentation during an ultrasound examination. There are no signs of labor progression, and the fetal heart rate is normal. What maternal position is often recommended to encourage fetal repositioning into a more favorable presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transverse lie is a fetal malpresentation that requires immediate attention to avoid complications like cord prolapse. Emergency cesarean delivery is typically the treatment of choice if labor progresses. Positions like the lateral recumbent, knee-chest, or Trendelenburg may temporarily improve maternal-fetal outcomes by relieving cord pressure and promoting fetal repositioning.
  • ➤ Transverse lie is a fetal malpresentation that requires immediate attention to avoid complications like cord prolapse.
  • ➤ Transverse lie
  • ➤ Emergency cesarean delivery is typically the treatment of choice if labor progresses.
  • ➤ Positions like the lateral recumbent, knee-chest, or Trendelenburg may temporarily improve maternal-fetal outcomes by relieving cord pressure and promoting fetal repositioning.
  • ➤ lateral recumbent, knee-chest, or Trendelenburg

questions.text: Which of the following statement concerning gluconeogenesis is correct?

options.label: B
options.text: It is important in maintaining blood glucose during a 2-day fast.

options.label: C
options.text: It is inhibited by a fall in the insulin/glucagon ratio.

options.label: D
options.text: It occurs in the cytosol of muscle cells.

questions.correct_answer: B. It is important in maintaining blood glucose during a 2-day fast.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It is important in maintaining blood glucose during a 2-day fast.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gluconeogenesis is the primary mechanism for maintaining blood glucose during prolonged fasting, especially after glycogen stores are depleted. This endergonic process occurs in the liver and kidneys and is stimulated by a low insulin/glucagon ratio, ensuring a continuous glucose supply for essential tissues like the brain and red blood cells.
  • ➤ Gluconeogenesis is the primary mechanism for maintaining blood glucose during prolonged fasting, especially after glycogen stores are depleted.
  • ➤ This endergonic process occurs in the liver and kidneys and is stimulated by a low insulin/glucagon ratio, ensuring a continuous glucose supply for essential tissues like the brain and red blood cells.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents with increasing dyspnea, purulent sputum production, and worsening shortness of breath over the past 2 days. Respiratory: Difficulty speaking in complete sentences. Prolonged expiratory phase. Decreased breath sounds. Other: Right ventricular lift. Bilateral 1+ pedal edema. Lab Findings: Fingerstick glucose: 90 mg/dL. Creatinine: 1.0 mg/dL. Which of the following arterial blood gas (ABG) findings would most likely be compatible with his clinical picture?

options.text: pH 7.30, bicarbonate 24 mEq/L, and anion gap of 10 mEq/L

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a 3-month history of feeling excessively sleepy during the day despite adequate nighttime sleep. questions.text: In contracting skeletal muscle, a sudden elevation of the sarcoplasmic calcium concentration will result in which of the following?

options.text: Activation of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP)-dependent protein kinase A

options.label: B
options.text: Conversion of cAMP to AMP by phosphodiesterase

options.label: C
options.text: Direct activation of glycogen synthase b

options.label: D
options.text: Direct activation of phosphorylase kinase b

questions.correct_answer: D. Direct activation of phosphorylase kinase b
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Direct activation of phosphorylase kinase b

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Calcium released during skeletal muscle contraction activates phosphorylase kinase b through binding to its calmodulin subunit. This activation initiates glycogenolysis, providing a rapid supply of energy to support muscle activity.
  • ➤ Calcium released during skeletal muscle contraction activates phosphorylase kinase b through binding to its calmodulin subunit. This activation initiates glycogenolysis, providing a rapid supply of energy to support muscle activity.
  • ➤ phosphorylase kinase b

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with bradycardia and hypotension after ingesting a large dose of metoprolol. Despite alpha-1 mediated vasoconstriction by noradrenaline, cardiac output does not improve significantly. What is the next best pharmacologic intervention?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glucagon is the preferred treatment for beta-blocker overdose as it directly enhances myocardial contractility and heart rate via cAMP.
  • ➤ Glucagon is the preferred treatment for beta-blocker overdose as it directly enhances myocardial contractility and heart rate via cAMP.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of excessive fear and avoidance of social situations. She reports intense anxiety about being embarrassed or judged by others during public interactions, which has severely impacted her academic performance. What is the first-line treatment for her condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Social anxiety disorder involves the fear of social situations, including situations that involve contact with strangers. Patients with this disorder are afraid of embarrassing themselves in social situations. DSM-5 provides a subtype of performance only . This subtype is characterized by a pronounced fear of performing or speaking in front of others, but not necessarily experiencing social anxiety in other contexts. The recommended treatments for Social Anxiety Disorder include: SSRIs, cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and Beta-blockers (e.g., propranolol).
  • ➤ Social anxiety disorder involves the fear of social situations, including situations that involve contact with strangers.
  • ➤ Patients with this disorder are afraid of embarrassing themselves in social situations. DSM-5 provides a subtype of performance only .
  • ➤ embarrassing themselves
  • ➤ performance only
  • ➤ This subtype is characterized by a pronounced fear of performing or speaking in front of others, but not necessarily experiencing social anxiety in other contexts.
  • ➤ The recommended treatments for Social Anxiety Disorder include: SSRIs, cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and Beta-blockers (e.g., propranolol).

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with a history of pseudophakic bullous keratopathy presents with worsening corneal edema and recurrent episodes of microbial keratitis. questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of severe anal pain during defecation and chronic constipation. questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of weakness in his right arm after using crutches for six weeks due to a leg fracture. He mentions that the crutches were possibly too tall for him, as they pressed hard into his armpit. On examination, there is a notable deficit in the extension of his wrist and fingers, and he has difficulty with thumb abduction. His sense of touch is diminished over the posterior aspect of his arm and forearm and the dorsum of his hand. Given the distribution of his symptoms, which structure is most likely to be affected by the prolonged use of crutches?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Posterior cord

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The posterior cord of the brachial plexus gives rise to the radial and axillary nerves. Prolonged axillary pressure, such as improper crutch use, can compress the posterior cord, leading to radial nerve injury characterized by wrist drop, weakness in thumb abduction, and sensory loss over the posterior arm, forearm, and dorsum of the hand.
  • ➤ The posterior cord of the brachial plexus gives rise to the radial and axillary nerves.
  • ➤ Prolonged axillary pressure, such as improper crutch use, can compress the posterior cord, leading to radial nerve injury characterized by wrist drop, weakness in thumb abduction, and sensory loss over the posterior arm, forearm, and dorsum of the hand.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was evaluated for burning sensations in his feet and clusters of small, red-purple spots on his skin. Laboratory studies revealed protein in his urine. Enzymatic analysis revealed a deficiency of α galactosidase, and enzyme replacement therapy was recommended. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fabry disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fabry disease is a rare X-linked lysosomal storage disorder caused by α-galactosidase A deficiency. Early symptoms include extremity pain and angiokeratomas. Progression leads to kidney and cardiac complications, emphasizing the importance of early diagnosis and enzyme replacement therapy.
  • ➤ Fabry disease is a rare X-linked lysosomal storage disorder caused by α-galactosidase A deficiency.
  • ➤ X-linked lysosomal storage disorder
  • ➤ Early symptoms include extremity pain and angiokeratomas.
  • ➤ Progression leads to kidney and cardiac complications, emphasizing the importance of early diagnosis and enzyme replacement therapy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with a 2-month history of right-sided facial pain, difficulty swallowing, and hearing loss. Neurological examination confirms trigeminal neuralgia on the right side. This presentation is most consistent with which of the following conditions?

Ans. A) Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trotter’s triad—palatal palsy, ipsilateral trigeminal neuralgia, and conductive hearing loss—is typically associated with nasopharyngeal carcinoma compressing or invading the cranial nerves.
  • ➤ Trotter’s triad—palatal palsy, ipsilateral trigeminal neuralgia, and conductive hearing loss—is typically associated with nasopharyngeal carcinoma compressing or invading the cranial nerves.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman, Ms. Priya from Mumbai, presents for her annual examination. Two weeks ago, she was treated for Chlamydia trachomatis infection diagnosed by nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) at an urgent care center. She was prescribed doxycycline orally twice daily for 7 days, and her symptoms resolved. Her partner also tested positive for Chlamydia and received treatment. Current Status: No sexual activity since her last visit. Asymptomatic during this visit. Current Testing Results: Pap test: Normal. NAAT for Chlamydia trachomatis: Positive. What is the most likely explanation for this positive test result?

options.label: C
options.text: Infection from a new sexual partner

questions.correct_answer: A. False-positive Chlamydia trachomatis test result
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Residual nucleic acid fragments from Chlamydia trachomatis can result in false-positive NAAT results for up to 3 weeks after successful treatment. Routine follow-up testing is not recommended unless symptoms persist or reinfection is suspected.
  • ➤ Residual nucleic acid fragments from Chlamydia trachomatis can result in false-positive NAAT results for up to 3 weeks after successful treatment.
  • ➤ Residual nucleic acid fragments
  • ➤ Routine follow-up testing is not recommended unless symptoms persist or reinfection is suspected.

questions.text: 25-year-old male receives an infusion of 150 mMol/L urea. Which of the following correctly describes the behavior of RBCs in this solution?

options.label: B
options.text: RBCs shrink, as the solution is hyperosmotic.

options.label: C
options.text: RBCs swell and lyse, as the solution becomes hypo-osmotic after urea equilibration.

options.label: D
options.text: RBC morphology remains unchanged, as the solution is iso-osmotic and isotonic.

questions.correct_answer: C. RBCs swell and lyse, as the solution becomes hypo-osmotic after urea equilibration.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Permeable solutes like urea render solutions hypo-osmotic, causing RBC swelling and lysis.
  • ➤ Permeable solutes like urea render solutions hypo-osmotic, causing RBC swelling and lysis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old construction worker presents to the clinic complaining of numbness over the back of his right hand following a fall from a ladder two weeks ago. He reports no weakness in his grip strength or fine motor tasks. On examination, there is a patch of sensory loss over the area marked in the image below, but motor strength in the forearm extensors is intact. Based on the anatomical distribution of sensory loss, which nerve is most likely affected?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The radial nerve's superficial branch provides sensory innervation to the dorsum of the lateral 3 ½ fingers and hand. Damage to the radial nerve in isolation often spares motor functions while causing sensory deficits in this region, as seen in this patient.
  • ➤ The radial nerve's superficial branch provides sensory innervation to the dorsum of the lateral 3 ½ fingers and hand.
  • ➤ superficial branch
  • ➤ Damage to the radial nerve in isolation often spares motor functions while causing sensory deficits in this region, as seen in this patient.

questions.text: In a criminal trial, a witness who initially agreed to testify for the prosecution later refuses to cooperate and provides contradictory statements during examination-in-chief. The prosecutor seeks the court's permission to ask leading questions. Under what circumstance can this be allowed?

options.label: A
options.text: Leading questions can be asked during examination-in-chief if the witness is an expert in the subject matter of the case.

options.label: B
options.text: Leading questions can be asked during examination-in-chief if the witness is hostile.

options.label: C
options.text: Leading question can be asked during examination-in-chief if the evidence of witness fails to prove that accused has done the crime.

questions.correct_answer: B. Leading questions can be asked during examination-in-chief if the witness is hostile.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Leading questions are typically reserved for cross-examination but may be used during examination-in-chief if a witness is declared hostile. This legal provision allows the court to extract crucial facts despite the witness’s uncooperative behavior.
  • ➤ Leading questions are typically reserved for cross-examination but may be used during examination-in-chief if a witness is declared hostile.
  • ➤ This legal provision allows the court to extract crucial facts despite the witness’s uncooperative behavior.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child who easily tires and has trouble walking is diagnosed with Duchenne muscular dystrophy, an X-linked recessive disorder. Genetic analysis shows that the patient’s gene for the muscle protein dystrophin contains a mutation in its promoter region. Of the choices listed, which would be the most likely effect of this mutation?

options.label: A
options.text: Initiation of dystrophin transcription will be defective.

options.label: B
options.text: Termination of dystrophin transcription will be defective.

options.label: C
options.text: Capping of dystrophin messenger RNA will be defective.

options.label: D
options.text: Splicing of dystrophin messenger RNA will be defective.

questions.correct_answer: A. Initiation of dystrophin transcription will be defective.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Initiation of dystrophin transcription will be defective

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Promoter region mutations impair the initiation of transcription by disrupting the recruitment of RNA polymerase II and other transcription factors. This results in reduced mRNA and protein production, as seen in disorders like Duchenne muscular dystrophy.
  • ➤ Promoter region mutations impair the initiation of transcription by disrupting the recruitment of RNA polymerase II and other transcription factors. This results in reduced mRNA and protein production, as seen in disorders like Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

questions.text: 45-year-old farmer presented to the emergency department with complaints of right-sided scrotal pain and progressive swelling for the past 5 days. He also reported fever with chills. Educational Objective:

  • ➤ With regards to scrotum:

questions.text: A 67-year-old man is hospitalized for congestive heart failure exacerbation and treated with intravenous diuretics. On hospital day 6, he develops a drop in platelet count to 62,000/µL (from 210,000/µL on admission) while receiving unfractionated heparin for DVT prophylaxis. Current Status: Subcutaneous heparin has been discontinued due to concern for heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). What is the best approach to prevent thromboembolism in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with suspected or confirmed HIT , discontinue all heparin products and initiate a non-heparin anticoagulant such as argatroban to reduce thromboembolic risk.
  • ➤ In patients with suspected or confirmed HIT , discontinue all heparin products and initiate a non-heparin anticoagulant such as argatroban to reduce thromboembolic risk.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with unexplained neurological symptoms, and a brain MRI is performed to evaluate potential pathology. The MRI reveals both T1-weighted and T2-weighted images. The radiologist notes significant differences in the appearance of various brain tissues, including cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and gray/white matter, depending on the MRI sequence used. Based on the given MRI characteristics, which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the comparison between T1 and T2 imaging sequences?

options.label: A
options.text: In T1WI, CSF appears hypointense, while in T2WI, CSF appears hyperintense.

options.label: B
options.text: In T1WI, both gray and white matter have the same signal intensity, while in T2WI, gray matter appears white and white matter appears gray.

options.label: C
options.text: T1WI is better for evaluating pathology, while T2WI is ideal for anatomical details.

options.label: D
options.text: In both T1WI and T2WI, most pathologies are hypointense, but the signal changes in T2WI are more pronounced.

questions.correct_answer: A. In T1WI, CSF appears hypointense, while in T2WI, CSF appears hyperintense.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) In T1WI, CSF appears hypointense, while in T2WI, CSF appears hyperintense.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ T1-weighted MRI typically shows CSF as hypointense, while T2-weighted MRI shows CSF as hyperintense. T2WI is better for evaluating pathologies, whereas T1WI is more suitable for anatomical details. Understanding these differences in MRI sequences is crucial for accurate interpretation in clinical practice.
  • ➤ T1-weighted MRI typically shows CSF as hypointense, while T2-weighted MRI shows CSF as hyperintense.
  • ➤ T2WI is better for evaluating pathologies, whereas T1WI is more suitable for anatomical details.
  • ➤ Understanding these differences in MRI sequences is crucial for accurate interpretation in clinical practice.

questions.text: A 3-month-old girl is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of progressive vision loss. Physical examination reveals cataracts, but no signs of liver damage or neurologic deficits. Urinalysis is positive for reducing sugar but negative for glucose. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for her condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Galactokinase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Galactokinase deficiency causes cataracts due to the accumulation of galactitol in the lens, which results from the reduction of galactose. The condition is relatively mild, lacking the systemic complications seen in galactose-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase deficiency. Urinalysis showing reducing sugar in the absence of glucose is a key diagnostic clue.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man sustains a severe alkali burn to his eye while working in an industrial setting. Despite initial irrigation and treatment, he presents three weeks later with persistent epithelial defects and chronic visual impairment. Which of the following complications is the hallmark of alkali injury?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Limbal stem cell deficiency

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Limbal stem cell deficiency is the hallmark complication of alkali injuries due to their deeper tissue penetration and destruction of limbal stem cells. The loss of limbal stem cells leads to persistent epithelial defects, conjunctivalization of the cornea, and chronic visual impairment. These changes significantly impact corneal transparency and vision.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Conjunctival scarring: Conjunctival scarring is a common long-term complication of ocular injuries but is not as immediate or severe as limbal stem cell deficiency in alkali burns.
  • • Option A. Conjunctival scarring:
  • • Option C. Corneal neovascularization: Corneal neovascularization occurs in later stages of healing as a secondary response to limbal stem cell loss. It is not the primary hallmark of alkali injuries.
  • • Option C. Corneal neovascularization:
  • • Option D. Symblepharon: Symblepharon refers to adhesions between the bulbar and palpebral conjunctiva. While it may occur in severe cases of ocular injuries, it is less common and less critical than limbal stem cell deficiency in alkali burns.
  • • Option D. Symblepharon:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Limbal stem cell deficiency is the defining feature of alkali injuries, leading to persistent epithelial defects and chronic visual impairment. Understanding this complication helps prioritize treatment and preventive measures for ocular injuries.

questions.text: A middle-aged male presents with fever and diarrhea for 1 week and acute onset abdominal pain for the past 6 hours. Early recognition and management are essential to prevent complications such as perforation.

questions.text: Assertion (A): Effector lymphocytes recirculate between blood and peripheral lymphoid organs after activation. Reason (R): Effector lymphocytes function by producing cytokines or directly attacking infected cells at the site of infection.

options.label: B
options.text: Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.

options.label: C
options.text: A is true, but R is false.

options.text: A is false, but R is true.

Ans.

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with chronic, painless nodules on his right forearm and hand, as shown in the image below. Ans. B) 6

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Glasgow Coma Scale-Pupils (GCS-P) is an extension of the GCS that includes the assessment of pupillary light response. It is used to evaluate the severity of brain injuries. The GCS-P score is derived by subtracting the pupillary score from the GCS score, providing a more comprehensive assessment of the patient's neurological status.
  • ➤ The Glasgow Coma Scale-Pupils (GCS-P) is an extension of the GCS that includes the assessment of pupillary light response.
  • ➤ It is used to evaluate the severity of brain injuries.
  • ➤ The GCS-P score is derived by subtracting the pupillary score from the GCS score, providing a more comprehensive assessment of the patient's neurological status.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man, Mr. Raj from Pune, presents with a 6-month history of intermittent palpitations. He describes the episodes as sudden-onset fluttering in the chest, lasting 30-40 minutes, and resolving spontaneously or after deep breathing maneuvers. The palpitations occur approximately once a month and are not associated with physical activity, chest pain, dizziness, dyspnea, or syncope. Examination Findings: Jugular venous pressure: 4 cm H₂O No cardiac murmurs or additional heart sounds Peripheral pulses: 2+ and symmetrical bilaterally Investigations: ECG is shown below. What is the most likely finding on ECG during an episode of palpitations?
questions.correct_answer: D. Regular narrow QRS complex tachycardia
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a young patient with intermittent palpitations and ECG findings suggestive of preexcitation , the most likely arrhythmia during episodes is regular narrow QRS complex tachycardia , typical of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) .
  • ➤ intermittent palpitations
  • ➤ preexcitation
  • ➤ regular narrow QRS complex tachycardia
  • ➤ paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT)

questions.text: Which of the following best differentiates the role of P-selectins from inflammasomes in the inflammatory response?

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ P-selectins mediate leukocyte recruitment, while inflammasomes are responsible for cytokine activation and pyroptosis.
  • ➤ P-selectins mediate leukocyte recruitment, while inflammasomes are responsible for cytokine activation and pyroptosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with hypertension and decreased renal function. Laboratory analysis reveals the following: GFR = 60 mL/min Renal plasma flow (RPF) = 240 mL/min What is the filtration fraction (FF), and what does it indicate about this patient's renal function?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) FF = 0.25; indicates compensatory hyperfiltration

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Filtration fraction (FF) = GFR/RPF = 60/240 = 0.25 (25%).
  • • In a healthy individual, FF is ~20%.
  • • A filtration fraction of 0.25 suggests compensatory hyperfiltration, a mechanism in which the remaining functional nephrons increase filtration to compensate for nephron loss or reduced filtration capacity.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The filtration fraction (FF) is the ratio of GFR to RPF and reflects the efficiency of filtration by the glomeruli. An FF > 0.20 suggests compensatory hyperfiltration, commonly seen in early stages of nephron loss or reduced renal function. Understanding FF helps evaluate renal function and its compensatory mechanisms in diseases such as hypertension or chronic kidney disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male farmer presents to the emergency department after suspected exposure to a pesticide. He reports applying a pesticide to his crops 4 days earlier. Since 2 days he started feeling agitated and nervous, followed by tremors which increased gradually. Today he also had a seizure and is bit confused. He has no signs of excessive salivation, diarrhea, or bradycardia. His vital signs (heart rate, blood pressure, respiratory rate) are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Organochlorine poisoning

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Organochlorine poisoning should be suspected in patients with neurotoxic symptoms such as agitation, tremors, seizures, and confusion following pesticide exposure. The absence of cholinergic signs helps distinguish organochlorine toxicity from organophosphate or carbamate poisoning. The gradual onset of symptoms is also characteristic of organochlorines.
  • ➤ Organochlorine poisoning should be suspected in patients with neurotoxic symptoms such as agitation, tremors, seizures, and confusion following pesticide exposure.
  • ➤ The absence of cholinergic signs helps distinguish organochlorine toxicity from organophosphate or carbamate poisoning.
  • ➤ The gradual onset of symptoms is also characteristic of organochlorines.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with progressive palmoplantar pigmentation. X-ray of the spine shows calcification of intervertebral discs. Urine analysis reveals a greenish-brown precipitate and blue-black supernatant fluid after adding Benedict's reagent. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alkaptonuria is a metabolic disorder characterized by homogentisic acid buildup, leading to ochronosis, darkened urine, and calcified intervertebral discs. Diagnosis is supported by urine discoloration with reagents and X-ray findings of spinal calcifications.

questions.text: A 7-year-old HIV-positive child with a CD4 count of 320 cells/mm³ and WHO stage 3 clinical status has been initiated on cotrimoxazole prophylaxis. When should prophylaxis be discontinued in this case?

options.label: B
options.text: When the CD4 count exceeds 350 cells/mm³, and the child has been on ART for at least 6 months.

options.label: C
options.text: Cotrimoxazole prophylaxis should continue indefinitely for all HIV-positive children.

options.label: D
options.text: Discontinuation should occur only when the child demonstrates undetectable viral loads for over 12 months.

questions.correct_answer: B. When the CD4 count exceeds 350 cells/mm³, and the child has been on ART for at least 6 months.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cotrimoxazole prophylaxis in HIV-positive children older than 5 years can be discontinued when the CD4 count is >350 cells/mm³, and ART has been effective for at least 6 months.
  • ➤ Cotrimoxazole prophylaxis in HIV-positive children older than 5 years can be discontinued when the CD4 count is >350 cells/mm³, and ART has been effective for at least 6 months.

questions.text: A 28-year-old construction worker presented to the emergency department after sustaining a stab wound to the neck during an altercation at his workplace. The knife entrance wound was located on the right side of the neck just lateral to the tip of the greater cornu of the hyoid bone. During the physical examination the patient was asked to protrude his tongue, which deviated to the right. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the physical signs in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Paralysis of the right genioglossus muscle permitted the left genioglossus to pull the tongue forward and turned the tip to the right side

options.label: B
options.text: Genioglossus originates from the lower genial tubercles of the mandible

options.label: C
options.text: The hypoglossal nerve descends in the neck between the internal carotid artery and the internal jugular vein.

options.label: D
options.text: At about the level of the tip of the greater cornu of the hyoid bone the hypoglossal nerve turns forward and crosses the internal and external carotid arteries and the lingual artery to enter the tongue

questions.correct_answer: B. Genioglossus originates from the lower genial tubercles of the mandible
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Genioglossus originates from the lower genial tubercles of the mandible

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hypoglossal nerve is the primary motor nerve of the tongue, and injury to it results in deviation of the tongue toward the side of the lesion due to unopposed action of the contralateral genioglossus muscle. The genioglossus muscle originates from the superior genial tubercles of the mandible and functions as the "safety muscle" by preventing the tongue from obstructing the airway.
  • ➤ The hypoglossal nerve is the primary motor nerve of the tongue, and injury to it results in deviation of the tongue toward the side of the lesion due to unopposed action of the contralateral genioglossus muscle.
  • ➤ The genioglossus muscle originates from the superior genial tubercles of the mandible and functions as the "safety muscle" by preventing the tongue from obstructing the airway.

questions.text: A clinician is comparing different ovulation-inducing medications for a patient with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Which of the following statements best explains why leuprolide has the unique ability to both stimulate and suppress ovulation depending on dosing?

options.label: A
options.text: Leuprolide acts as a selective GnRH receptor modulator, changing its effect based on estrogen levels.

options.label: B
options.text: Leuprolide’s effect is dose-dependent, with high doses suppressing and low doses stimulating the pituitary.

options.label: C
options.text: The effect of leuprolide depends on its administration schedule, pulsatile or continuous.

options.label: D
options.text: Leuprolide directly affects ovarian cells to either promote or inhibit follicle maturation.

questions.correct_answer: C. The effect of leuprolide depends on its administration schedule, pulsatile or continuous.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Leuprolide’s ability to either stimulate or suppress ovulation is determined by its mode of administration—pulsatile or continuous.
  • ➤ Leuprolide’s ability to either stimulate or suppress ovulation is determined by its mode of administration—pulsatile or continuous.

questions.text: A patient presents with a foreign body in the right cornea. Which would be the topical anesthetic of choice to remove it?
questions.explanation:

questions.text: Which of the following describes the movements known as pronation and supination?

options.label: A
options.text: The flexing of the arm with respect to the forearm around the elbow.

options.label: B
options.text: The swivelling of the foot to the medial and lateral directions.

options.label: C
options.text: The twisting of the wrist while the elbow is held motionless.

options.label: D
options.text: The rotation at the shoulder that causes the arm to describe a cone shape.

questions.correct_answer: C. The twisting of the wrist while the elbow is held motionless.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The twisting of the wrist while the elbow is held motionless

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pronation and supination are movements of the forearm occurring at the radioulnar joints, allowing the hand to rotate from palm-up to palm-down positions. These movements are critical for activities involving wrist rotation, such as turning a doorknob or handling tools.
  • ➤ Pronation and supination are movements of the forearm occurring at the radioulnar joints, allowing the hand to rotate from palm-up to palm-down positions.
